title: Extinction Rebellion to defy police protest ban and challenge it in court
text:
Police remove a protester from Trafalgar Square last night (Picture: PA)

Extinction Rebellion (XR) say they will take the police to court and defy a move banning all of the group’s demonstrators from London.

Two former officers told the Victoria Derbyshire Show that the Metropolitan Police are ‘being really sloppy with the law’ and that the ruling ‘won’t stand up in court’.

The decision to ban protesters has drawn widespread criticism, as police began removing the environmental group from Trafalgar Square, following more than a week of disruption.

An ex detective sergeant and an ex police inspector condemned the decision to outlaw all XR protests across London from 9pm onwards last night.

Paul Stephens said he had clarified with police that there was no ban on processing (a section 12 order) but was told that because there was a ban on assembling police would not allow them to do either.

Advertisement

Advertisement

He said the group would seek a judicial review of the ‘ridiculous’ decision.

Police arrest a Green Party Member of the European Parliament for the West Midlands while clearing an Extinction Rebellion environmental activists campsite at Trafalgar square yesterday (Picture: Getty Images Europe)

A protester is carried away from the City of London during a protest yesterday (Picture: PA)

Another former Met Officer, Richard Ecclestone, added: ‘My concern is that peaceful protest has been completely shut down by the actions of the Metropolitan Police.

‘I am not sure that is proportionate – we are facing an emergency here and the government is failing to act on that, so it is really important that concerned citizens are able to express themselves peacefully.’

Exclusive: Extinction Rebellion tell us they’re going to take Met Police to court over their ban on the climate change protestors. These two demonstrators are ex-cops themselves and say they’ll breach the ban and be back on the streets today #VictoriaLIVE pic.twitter.com/oxaq8RFAEz — Victoria Derbyshire (@vicderbyshire) October 15, 2019

The Mayor of London, Sadiq Khan, said earlier that he was ‘seeking further information from senior officers’ about the decision and ‘why it was necessary’.

He continued: ‘I believe the right to peaceful and lawful protest must always be upheld.

Mayor of London Sadiq Khan has asked for more information about the move (Picture: NurPhoto)

‘However, illegal action by some protesters over the past eight days has put undue pressure on already overstretched police officers, and demonstrators should bear this in mind when considering any further actions’.

Advertisement

Advertisement

Since last Monday, the group have been engaged in an ‘international rebellion’ to draw attention to the climate crisis.

In Britain, protesters have disrupted London City Airport, demonstrated at the BBC and blockaded the capital’s financial district, in a similar action to last April.

Ex-boxer Ricky Hatton gives Paul Gascoigne character reference in court

As of 5pm last night, some 1,445 arrests had been made.

Police are now reportedly beginning to clear Vauxhall Pleasure Gardens of tents and protesters as they enforce the new ruling.

The Shadow Home Secretary, Diane Abbott condemned the decision to ban XR protests.

She said: ‘The Labour Party unequivocally supports the right to protest. The Extinction Rebellion protests have been largely peaceful and brought vital attention to the climate emergency – the most important issue facing the world.

‘Any criminal acts should of course be handled by police, but an outright ban is wrong and completely contrary to Britain’s long-held traditions of policing by consent, freedom of speech, and the right to protest.’

In a statement, the Met said: ‘Any assembly linked to the Extinction Rebellion ‘Autumn Uprising’…must cease their protest(s) within London by 9pm on Monday.

Advertisement

‘Protestors have been notified, and given an opportunity to leave the site. Anyone who fails to comply with the condition is liable for arrest and prosecution.’

Deputy Assistant Commissioner Laurence Taylor added: ‘These conditions have been imposed due to the continued breaches of the section 14 condition previously implemented, and ongoing serious disruption to the community.

‘Since the beginning of this operation officers have been working hard to keep London moving. There have been more than 1,400 arrests, and a number of people have been charged. The policing operation continues, and we will continue to take action against anyone engaged in unlawful protests at locations targeted by Extinction Rebellion.’

description: Section 14 ruling for any Extinction Rebellion protest across all of London 'ridiculous, ex police officers say.
